ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Auction theory, internet advertisement technology, mechanism design
We learned a lot about mechanism design, with a focus on auctions, and how this is used by tech companies.
I developed and gained insight into various auction designs. I learned about how to present my slides on auctions to the class.
Learned a variety of auction formats and their practical applications.
Deep dive into academic Economics, with a focus on mechanism design

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strengths are that the courses focused on an interesting set of topics, and that Professor Bergemann is a brilliant instructor.

A strength is that Professor Bergemann and O'Neill are kind and try and help us during our presentations. They do not ask super rigorous questions during the presentations, more expanding questions and if you do not know the answer they will help you out. Another strength is that the class has nice people and outside of the presentation and paper, the workload is not too excessive. One weakness is that we did not get a rubric for how we would be graded in the class. Perhaps to engage students more, they could have one pair of students assigned to another to peer grade their presentations.

Really enjoyed this course! The topics covered were exceptionally interesting. However, I wish the format of the class was differentits very student presentation focused. While I understand that its important for students to develop presentation skills, I would love to have heard from the professors more for lectures.
Phenomenal class  everyone with a sufficient background to understand will appreciate this course

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: You probably aren't taking this unless it's for a requirement, but I really enjoyed this class. I think the econ focus makes the class very engaging, and it's accessible in the sense that you don't need to have an insanely rigorous math background to understand what's going on. I didn't know anything about auction theory beforehand, but it's really interesting and I feel that I've learned a lot. I really enjoyed the focus on math research because I had never read a math research paper before this class, and it was great looking into current work that is happening in math and how it's applicable to real life. We also had a guest speaker come who was really cool. I definitely think this is a great math senior seminar to take!

I would recommend the course if you need it for Econ/Math, but probably not beyond that. The course is basically structured so that students teach most of the time, and I personally do not love this, as it reads the material to feel somewhat disconnected, and professors tend to do a better job than students at teaching.

I would recommend this course to people who are interested in learning about the different types of auctions. This is also a requirement for the Econ/Math major so not entirely an option but Professor Bergemann is nice and even though this had an additional paper compared to Math 480, it was worth it to have a nicer professor in a low stress class.
Yes! Especially w/ prof. Bergemann, he is awesome, funny, nice, and a joy to learn from!
Yes, the professors made this class interesting and worthwhile.
Yes, if youre interested in this field its a no brainer
